reviewText: Series three of Inspector Lewis is absolutely first class.  It's delightful to learn that Western culture can still make films at this level of excellence. The series features the best actors and actresses in the world, and the production levels are not being exceeded anywhere (Certainly not in the United States, where people watch the likes of Law And Order).My only problem is with the writing.  In the first place, the plots are fantastically complex.  After completing a film, try sitting down with a large pad and attempting to recreate the story line.  Do the writers really need four sub-plots?  Why not try just three?  Secondly, it's a shame that the same, stale anti-Catholicism appears in several of the scripts.  How about making fun of some Church of England clergy...or, better yet, why not show at least one favorable priest or nun?  Just one.  That said, the scripts for Inspector Lewis: Series 3 are top notch. No one, to my knowledge, is presenting better scripts for television these days.  The timely lesson for Hollywood: Quality does not have to depend on exploding cars, car chases, teen love scenes, and actors from daytime soaps.In short, may the series continue!
Title: N/A

I truly enjoy there repartee.I hope Lawrence can finally stop smokingHappy to see the boss of these two great guys given a chance to look stylish...it's about time!!!!!!

reviewText: I love the Inspector Lewis series. Saw Morse, then most of Lewis, fresh on UK TV, and now watch it HD on local PBS station in the States. Ordered Series 1 & 2 and was profoundly disappointed that PBS choose to release crappy DVDs without subtitles (my Sony Bravia system with HDMI inter-linked components will not play broadcast type captions). I like subtitles I can turn on and off easily, due to hearing difficulties. And the picture quality was so awful- like an old VHS tape that had been played one too many times.Then I got this Series 3 set and was most pleased to see 1) DVD subtitles, and 2) a much improved picture quality. Not, sadly, the HD I see on my local PBS station. I suppose PBS will need to enter the 21st Century first, and realize that Blu - Ray, or some other high quality medium is the standard now. But at least it's not like Series 1 & 2, which is like watching TV through a mat of wet Kleenex.So, welcome to the last decade PBS! Thank you for starting to use DVD quality on your DVD disks. Now just let yourselves tune in a bit more, and edge in to all the recent technological developments and take the next step up to HD.
summary: PBS finally getting it right- When Blu Ray?

reviewText: The show is enjoyable, even fun. However, when you watch season after season in a short time-span (e.g., a month), the episodes start to blur together and even seem to have plot structures that duplicate Inspector Morse. Additionally, the plot devices are often set up to obfuscate--always discount the 'early' suspicious suspect, and look for a 'late-comer', especially if a woman. The single star rating is in protest over the fact that the 'start' screen is arranged so that one can (as I did) accidentally press 'buy' when all one wanted to do was watch for free via Prime.

reviewText: Season three (3) of PBS' "Inspector Lewis" has restored my love of this series.  I adored Season one (1) of "Inspector Lewis"; Season two (2) left me rather indifferent to the series.  I found the stories in Season two (2), to me, to be rather convoluted and hard to follow with the actors just did not seeming, to me, to be "into"  their roles.  Season three (3) however, is really good with, to me, very well written and directed mysteries plus they are so very well acted.Kevin Whatley as Detective Lewis and Laurence Fox as his young detective partner, James Hathaway certainly make a good team(not always seeing "eye to eye" regarding a case) bouncing off each other wonderfully while solving some dastardly murders in Season three (3) which also has some known actors in Britain such as Rubert Graves ("Room with a View", "Maurice", etc) Joanna Lumley ("Ab Fab"), Nathaniel Parker ("Inspector Lynley", "Bleak House", etc.).  Indeed Lewis and Hathaway, although the opposite of each other mainly generationally, do make a good detective team.  Yes, Inspector Morse's ghost is ever present but, I feel, Lewis and Hathaway in Season three (3) have certainly come into their "own" with this series making for a really entertaining series.  I know that I really enjoyed Season three (3).Season 3 is presented on three discs with  five (5) episodes running about an hour and a half per episode.  If you are into good detective mysteries, buy this set.
summary: ENJOYING THE INSPECTOR LEWIS SERIES AGAIN

reviewText: Inspector Lewis and Sergeant Hathaway investigate the death of a university Master who fell down stairs. Was he murdered? Did he accidently fall? Was it suicide? Why was he in the university observatory? Why did this atheist suddenly and secretly begin to attend church? Why did he feel the need to go to confession? Why did he hide his church attendance from his wife?There are very interesting subplots in this film and fascinating characters. Some intertwine into the main plot; others are red herrings, which is good. The interplay between Lewis and Hathaway is delightful to watch, as usual.

reviewText: As another reviewer mentioned, this set includes a carryover ("Counter Culture Blues") from the previous year's UK release.  Unfortunately it's the stinker of the series in my opinion and is pretty much a rip off of an earlier Midsomer episode ("The Axeman Commeth"). Lewis even uses that title in a line from this unfortunate entry. However, the ship is soon righted with the succeeding 4 offerings and returns to it's slightly melancholy roots with Lewis even dabbling  in a romance of sorts with Dr. Hobson.  The story lines are inventive and unpredictable and the cinematography is beautifully done as is the case with all the Morse/Lewis mysteries.  My major gripe and the reason for the 4 star rating is the apparent inability to move Lewis into the iconoclastic lead character these British mysteries tend to thrive on.  Morse, Rebus, Frost are all flawed characters that solve crimes despite their shortcomings while Lewis remains the dependable plodder. Considering the genesis of this series, I'd like to see the central character develop a few of Morse's foibles; perhaps an old jag and a serious preference for "real" beer would set him right.  A big plus for this series however is that PBS has dropped the obsequious host introducing each episode to North American audiences and restored the original content to match the U.K. broadcasts.  However, I am concerned that this series is moving away from the "sequel" mode.  Lewis is becoming a little too much like prop furniture on the set and not enough of an iconoclastic lead like his former mentor.Grumbling aside, this is an excellent series with inventive story lines centered around the town of Oxford and it's namesake university.  And, just like in "Inspector Morse" the university remains an uncredited cast member.  Speaking of cast members; they're uniformly excellent with Laurance Fox's portrayal of DS Hathaway a standout.  I just wish Lewis would grab the title role rather than merely being a member of the ensemble cast.  As Morse might say; "Carpe Diem, Lewis!".
summary: maturing but not quite there yet

reviewText: Inspector Lewis and his side kick Hathaway are the perfect duo. Hathaway is a graduate of Oxford and was going to be a priest. He has a high IQ and a brilliant mind. Lewis remains the man of the street type of detective who doggedly pursues justice. I think this series could be called Inspector Hathaway as he is as much a part of the success of this series as is Lewis. Though not as brilliant as Foyles War (Nothing is) it will likely become one of your favorites if you like English Mysteries. Unlike American mysteries you must pay close attention to the Brits mysteries. They are very complicated to say the least. Just keeping up with the characters is tough much less solving the crimes. The Brits seem to do it on a low budget with fine actors. People like Honeysuckle Weeks in Foyles War and Hathaway in Inspector Lewis are big contributors even if you do not recognize it. I have watched all of the Foyle's War series at least twice and on my way to doing the same with Inspector Lewis. The English are masters at producing great mysteries without a lot of blood and gore. They are a thinking man/woman's type of mystery. You cannot get up and go get a cup of coffee while the show is on or you might be lost when you return. PBS is to be congratulated for their productions of both English drama and mysteries such as Lewis, Foyle, Downton Abbey, Upstairs Downstairs, Jane Eyre. They consistently produce fine entertainment. You see many of the same actors in many of their productions as being a small island nation they do not have so many actors to choose from.

reviewText: I cannot seem to watch enough of Inspector Lewis and his partner Hathaway. Trust comes to their relationship slowly.

reviewText: "Dead of Winter" was one of the best Inspector Lewis episodes. In this, we discover a bit of Sgt. Hathaway's past, and he has a  romance with a former childhood companion who is about to get married. We visit a very interesting Castle with a past and the episode opens with a set of re-enactors, who annually reproduce a skirmish that took place near the site during the English Civil War between defenders of King Charles versus Parliament. In all nicely done, well written, interestingly plotted and brilliant location scenery.

reviewText: This series seems a more sophisticated series than Morse in terms of dialogue, scenery and plots.  Morse is iconic--but this spinoff Inspector Lewis series is a delight in its own way.  Casting is wonderful, plots are complex, and dialogue is original and full of surprises. I like James Hathaway's new haircut and it was great to see him actually grin with teeth showing in the second show.  He tends to steal scenes, but that's allowed.He's the perfect cerebral foil to Lewis who seems to have brightened up since working with him.  This series is a total delight that keeps me on the treadmill.  I hope they make years of these shows.  I'll never tire of them. The variety of plots in this season is welcome.  Quite an original array.  If you like classic British police procedurals, you should enjoy this series and season.

reviewText: This show is what American TV should be. Engrossing , while not gross, and intellectually stimulating while being vastly entertaining. The two leads work so well together that it at times is difficult to remember that they are not real, but just actors. One of the strengths of this series is that they have failings just as all we mortals do. It is one of the very few series where I am actually sad at the end because I wish it could go on for several hours more. The background of Oxford makes this the intellectual treat that it is. The architecture and the rooms themselves are so fascinating to one in the states that I times i just pause the show to view the rooms up close. Besides try to imagine any, and I mean any American series, where Frederich Nietzsche's writings are and integral part of the plot . This right now is far and away my favorite TV show be it comedy or drama.

reviewText: "Inspector Lewis Series 3" comprises one episode from the UK Series 3 and four episodes from the UK Series 4, for a total of five 90-minute episodes. If Hathaway's haircut didn't make "Counterculture Blues" obviously from an earlier season, its inferior pacing would. The filmmakers find just the right pace for these mysteries in the UK Series 4, which makes this the best season yet. The intricacy of the plots holds the audience's attention, rather than seeming overdone. I can't say that the writers have mastered endings yet, but, in the cases that they go off the rails toward the end, they are quite enjoyable until that point. We get a taste of Hathaway's mysterious past in "The Dead of Winter" and of Dr. Hobson's in "Falling Darkness". We get a little history in "The Dead of Winter" and "Dark Matter", which is unusual in that it revolves around one of Oxford's science departments, rather than the usual humanities for which the university is famous. Subtitles are available in English SDH. These are the episodes:"Counterculture Blues" revolves around a group of aging rock stars. A teenager's body is found in the woods, run over repeatedly by a car, and the vicar of a nearby church complains about the neighbor hunting during services on Sunday. The neighbor is Richie Maguire (David Hayman), retired co-vocalist of "Midnight Addiction", a `60s band that Lewis admired in his youth. The band's iconic female lead singer, Esme Ford (Joanna Lumley) has turned up after a 35-year absence during which she was thought dead. And their former manager Vernon Oxe (Simon Callow) is angling to reunite the band and make a fortune. But it looks like the young man was murdered just outside Richie's gate, and there are more bodies on the way, all somehow connected to the band.A man is shot with a real bullet during a battle reenactment at Crevecoeur Hall in "The Dead of Winter". Then an Oxford history scholar is found murdered on a tour bus that visited the estate earlier that day. It turns out that DS Hathaway grew up near Crevecoeur Hall, where his father was estate manager. So it is an awkward homecoming for him, meeting Scarlett Mortmaigne (Camilla Arfwedson), daughter of Lord Augustus Mortmaigne (Richard Johnson), and the butler Paul Hopkiss (Pip Carter), who were his childhood playmates. But Hathaway and DI Lewis are there to solve a murder, which may be connected to the disappearance of the current estate manager's wife 9 years ago and perhaps to a legendary 17th century treasure."Dark Matter" brings us back to Oxford University, when Andrew Crompton, Master of Gresham College, is found dead in the observatory. Crompton was an amateur astronomer, whose friends included Sir Arnold (Robert Hardy) and  Lady Gwen Raeburn (Diana Quick), a famous composer and his astrophysicist wife. The day of his death, Crompton expressed excitement over some event that would take place on Friday afternoon at 3:15 PM. As Lewis and Hathaway try to decipher his behavior, their investigation is complicated by a Head Porter, Robert Temple (Warren Clarke), and his housekeeper wife (Annabelle Apsion). Meanwhile, Dr. Laura Hobson (Clare Holman), the pathologist, is rehearsing a concert with some of the suspects."Your Sudden Death Question" interrupts everyone's holiday weekend. Six teams of two people each are competing in a "quiz weekend", or trivia contest, hosted by Marcus Richards (Alan Davies) on the Oxford campus. One of the contest's most gregarious competitors, Ethan Croft (Adam James), a heavy-drinking, womanizing, brilliant Russian translator, is found dead in the fountain. The campus is locked down, and Inspector Lewis must cancel his opera weekend and Hathaway his music festival to find out which of the remaining competitors -the soldiers, Oxford dons, lawyers, young mothers, primary school teacher, or students- had motive for murder. This is a old-fashioned cloistered murder mystery with a bit of humor owing to everyone's frustrated weekend.It's Halloween in Oxford, and Dr. Hobson is preparing for a reunion with her old college housemates in "Falling Darkness". One of them, Dr. Ligeia Willard, is unfortunately found dead before they can get together. Then another murder occurs in connection with the old house that Hobson shared with four roommates in her college days. This places DI Lewis and DS Hathaway in the awkward position of having to investigate their colleague's recent movements and old university friendships. But Dr. Willard also worked in stem cell research, on a project that brought regular death threats and hid a scandal of its own. This mystery is well-paced but goes off the rails toward the end. It also leaves the motive for a couple of murders unexplained.
summary: Improved Pacing and Growing Rapport between Detectives Make This a Strong Season.

reviewText: Having watched most of Morse episodes I was rather dubious about Lewis. However the 'new' Lewis and his side-kick are able to meander through the various murders and not only solve them but leave us gasping for the next episode. The writers have done a great job of transforming Lewis into the loner (now widowed) married to his job (just like Morse) and his new assistant who is more cultured, better educated but who is his subordinate. Their uneasy relationship develops into mutual admiration and their different skills and perspectives enable them to solve their cases. Many guest appearances from well known actors of both the silver and big screen make this one of the best of British mystery dramas. My top favourite is New Tricks and this comes a close second. If you liked Morse you won't be disappointed. This is a great series.

reviewText: With a new set of writers and production team, the Lewis series is far more intelligent with more complex and intriguing plots than the Morse series.  Lewis, in a very nice touch, listens to Tosca, tries to go to Glyndebourne for an opera with Dr. Hobson as his date--would love to see them get together as a couple.  From the pilot now through Series Three, in almost every one, there is an homage to Morse--crossword puzzles, anagrams, opera, and the more subtle such as Lewis telling his Sergeant, James Hathaway, the he actually is a Wagner man (like Morse), but stating he liked Wagner especially if it is conducted by Knappertsbusch.  One has to recall that Morse was pleasantly surprised when Lewis happened to purchase a recording of Parsifal, but Lewis pronounced the conductor's name "Nappertsbusch" and the always last word was Morse telling Lewis that it's actually pronounced "K-nappernatsbusch."  Since I have probably watched the Morse episodes at least 20 times, all of these wonderful small snippets in remembrance of not only Morse, but of John Thaw, the actor, are wonderful, and bring back both a little bit of happiness and sadness concomitantly.Whether you were/are a fan of Morse, you can't help but be a fan of Lewis.  With now the underling being the Cambridge educated cop that niggles at Lewis, it's a nice change from the screaming of Morse at Lewis from above.  Maybe that's the intelligence of this series.  As Americans who are used to TV shows going up to 20 seasons with 26 shows per season, and the English series (not including soaps and Dr. Who) rarely going longer than 6 seasons and no more than 6-7, and usually 4-6 shows per season, we fans can't get enough of Oxford murders.If these were priced at twice the price, they would still be worth the money.  If you are not yet addicted to Lewis, you must start with the Pilot episode which sets the tone of the new series--new Superintendant, and female to boot.  Tough when she needs to be, but understanding.  And she converses with Hathaway almost as much as Lewis.The best "cop" show right now.  Midsomer Murders, for all it's many, many years running thanks mostly to American audiences who could not and apparently cannot get enough, may Lewis go on until he retires, many, many years from now.
summary: Absolutely the Best Police Drama on TV on Either Side of the Ocean

reviewText: I have always loved the actor who plays Lewis and his sergeant Hathaway is splendid as well.  I love the type of relationship between these two that has been created by the writers and carried out with great skill by the actors.  The development of the stories is always intriguing and of course the always present art and music and almost complete lack of car chases is nothing short of joy for me as a viewer.  I never tire of this series and watch it and re-watch constantly.  My only complaint is that so often the story lines are so politically liberal making sure that the viewer knows that any type of belief in God is ignorant and antiquated.  As a believer, I do resent this and don't feel it is the job of the entertainment industry to indoctrinate me spiritually when there are so many interesting story lines that don't necessarily need to attack and demonize religion of every kind with the possible exception of Eastern beliefs.  I continue watching with great zeal but with the periodic eye-rolling that accompanies watching anything that is politically heavy-handed.  Alas not too many shows are lacking in this department, Lewis included, thus, for me, only four stars.
summary: A little too liberal for me.

reviewText: There seems to be plenty of confusion in trying to get hold of a decent copy of Inspector Lewis in the US - not only are there reports that scenes have been cut out of episodes, but I haven't been able to find series 3 on Amazon.com. That is, the episodes described here as encompassing series 3 are actually part of series 4 in the UK. Working with the UK editions, series 3 of Lewis contains the episodes "Allegory of Love," "Quality of Mercy," "The Point of Vanishing", and "Counterculture Blues", whilst series 4 is made up of "The Dead of Winter", "Dark Matter", "Your Sudden Death Questions" and "Falling Darkness."Yet according to the other reviews here, the US series 3 is made up of "Counterculture Blues" (from series 3) followed by "The Dead of Winter", "Dark Matter", "Your Sudden Death Questions" and "Falling Darkness" (from series 4). But you can tell that "Counterculture Blues" belongs to a different season by the change in the lead actors' haircuts. Confused yet? Somewhere along the line three episodes have gone missing from the American release, with the last episode being squished into the next season. A full list of episodes in their correct order can easily be found on Wikipedia, but my advice would be to invest either in a multi-regional DVD player and get the British DVDs, or go for "Lewis: The Complete Series," where at least you know you'll get ALL the episodes.Lewis is a quintessential British detective series, fitting considering it's a spin-off to the hugely successful "Morse". Here Morse's young sergeant has been promoted to an inspector, taking over as the central character with a sergeant of his own. Robert Lewis is a hard-working, by-the-books investigator, paired with the droll, laconic, and deceptively laid-back James Hathaway. Both men have their own dark history: Lewis is haunted by the death of his wife in a hit-and-run accident, and Hathaway was in training to be a priest before a crisis of faith led him to the police force instead. However, they make a great team, combing Lewis's experience and instincts with Hathaway's zeal and higher education.Also on board is Superintendent Jean Innocent, who oversees all of Lewis's cases (and who butts heads with him on more than one occasion), and Doctor Laura Hobson, the pathologist with a rather dark sense of humor. Each provides a dose of estrogen to the cast, and in the latter case, a possible love interest for Lewis. The show never delves too deeply into their characterization, but the four of them form an effective core cast, and are written and performed as realistic three-dimensional characters that ground the show.All of the mysteries are set in Oxford, and the show takes full advantage of this, with lingering panning shots over its beautiful architecture and winding streets. It's pure eye-candy, and in this particular season, many of the storylines are set in or around the university, with plenty of allusions to scholarly subjects and the subtle, on-going tension that exists between wealthy students and normal working-class citizens. Not only are many of the episode titles based on literary quotes, but the episodes themselves are chocked full of references to famous writers and their work - whether it be a character called Titus in "The Dead of Winter" (who happens to be the young heir to a great estate) or a plot lifted straight out of the pages of Edgar Allan Poe in "Falling Darkness". Also fun is playing the game of "spot the famous British guest star". Since Britain has (comparatively speaking) a very small pool of actors, there are always going to be familiar faces popping up in all of their most popular TV shows, and Lewis is no exception.This particular box-set contains five ninety-minute mysteries, though it would appear from some of the other reviews that at least ten minutes have been cut out of the run-time of each episode. Like I said, perhaps it's best if you track down the UK editions."Counterculture Blues" deals with what first appears to be a minor call-out to a vicar complaining about gun-shots going off on a neighboring estate every Sunday during his service. When Lewis and Hathaway arrive to sort things out, Lewis ends up rather star-struck on realizing that the men he's been sent to warn are actually the aging members of the rock band "Midnight Addiction" that he was a big fan of in his youth. The plot thickens when the body of a young teenager is found run over outside singer Richie Maguire's gates at about the same time the female vocalist Esme Ford returns to the band after a thirty-five year old absence, during which she was believed dead. Lewis suspects that the two occurrences are connected, especially with the band's obnoxious manager urging the band to reunite and stage a come-back.During a battle reenactment at Crevecoeur Hall in "The Dead of Winter," a man is shot and wounded by a stray bullet - which is very suspicious considering the entire thing was simply meant to be a performance. Coming quickly on the heels of this is the discovery of a body on a tour bus that visited the Crevecoeur estate earlier in the day. Hathaway seems strangely hesitant in visiting the place, and it soon becomes apparent why: his father was estate manager of the place and he grew up with the young daughter of the current lord and the family's loyal butler. Sparks begins to fly between him and his childhood friend Lady Scarlett Mortmaigne (despite her recent engagement) and it's up to Lewis to keep Hathaway on track, what with the investigation leading to the apparent suicide of the latest estate manager, the disappearance of his wife nine years earlier, and a legendary treasure said to be buried somewhere on the grounds.Based more on history than the usual classics or literary context, this is a rather Gothic murder mystery filled with family secrets. The cast seems to have stepped right out of a game of Clue (complete with a murder victim called Doctor Black and a suspect called Scarlett) and a manor house dating back to the 17th century. It also sheds some light on Hathaway's mysterious past and includes a fun subplot with the hidden treasure that takes Lewis to several key landmarks across the estate."Dark Matter" returns to the more familiar setting of Oxford University, this time to the astronomy department where the Master of Gresham College, Andrew Crompton, is found dead in the observatory. Leaving behind a grieving widow and a number of other suspects readying themselves for a concert in his memory (with the orchestra including Laura Hobson on the clarinet), Lewis and Hathaway clash over the ethical quandary of whether or not a priest should share the dead man's confession and explain why he expected "a surfeit of joy" on Friday afternoon at 3:15pm.There are plenty of suspects to go around in this one, as well as a keen look at the nature of faith and the moral framework it imposes on a person's life. As one suspect bitterly points out: "it's wonderful how people pick and mix morality to suit themselves." Of all the episodes in this set, this one is probably the best-plotted, with plenty of motivation to go around, including blackmail, love affairs, mental illness and lingering traces of the class divide.Lewis and Hathaway are looking forward to a Bank Holiday Weekend in "Your Sudden Death Question" (Lewis has a date at the opera and Hathaway is off to a music festival) when their plans are cancelled by a murder. A quiz weekend was being held on the Oxford campus, an event in which several teams of contestants pay for food and board and partake in a trivia contest - in this case, one hosted by a rather dodgy organizer. The most promising contender was the shady, arrogant, womanizing, rakish Ethan Croft, now found dead in a water fountain.This is a classic "closed murder mystery" in which the suspects are all gathered in one place and not permitted to leave until the detectives find their killer. And there's plenty to choose from, with teams made up of army soldiers, old dons, young students, lawyers, mothers and teachers, many with a reason to want Ethan Croft dead. More of a character study than most, this episode explores the lives of all the suspects and the mindset needed to enter into what appears to be a rather pointless hobby.Finally, "Falling Darkness" is a quintessential Halloween episode, filled with plenty of terrifying components and a look into the past of Laura Hobson. Whilst preparing to meet up with her old college flat-mates, Hobson is called out to a crime-scene - and faints straight into Lewis's arms when she sees that the dead body is that of her friend Ligeia Willard, whom she had spoken to on the phone just minutes before. It's an unsettling experience, one that's about to get worse when a follow-up case takes place in the very house where she and her friends used to live. Forced to concede that Laura is somehow wrapped up in the proceedings, Lewis reluctantly plies her for information on her past and begins to investigate her former flat-mates.What starts off as one of the strongest and most compelling episodes of the series goes a little haywire by the end, with a couple of subplots that trail off into nowhere and a few red herrings that go unexplained (what was the deal with the psychic?) but it nevertheless remains a tense and rather frightening viewing experience.In all, "Lewis" is a high quality drama with smooth pacing, solid writing and a beautiful visual style. The amount of talent it manages to attract is proof enough of its worth, so keep your eyes open for the following thespians: Simon Callow (Charles Dickens inDoctor Who), Perdita Weeks (Lady Georgiana Grex fromTitanic), Nathaniel Parker (Inspector Lynley), Lucy Griffiths (Marian fromRobin Hood), Alex Price (Gilbert fromBeing Human), Timothy West (Sir Deadlock fromBleak House), Alan Davies (Jonathan Creek), Robert Hardy (Cornelius Fudge from theHarry Potterfranchise), Rupert Graves (Inspector Lestrade fromSherlock), and Joanna Lumley fromAbsolutely Fabulous, who still looks ravishing.

reviewText: I own the entire Morse series and, over the years, have watched every episode many times over. I have watched the series, with the greatest pleasure and admiration. John Thaw, as Morse, is superb and the entire series is most expertly produced. The all round excellence puts the Morse series in a class of its own - NEARLY!Lewis has superseded the legend and this finely acted and superbly produced series MUST, NOW, TAKE PRIDE OF PLACE!Lewis's transformation - from being subordinate as a Sergeant, to being in charge as an Inspector - has been accomplished with great skill and acting ability. The story lines and the outstanding photography carry the 'Detective genre' a few steps forward - even from Morse.Lewis is a pre-eminent series - with both Kevin Whately and Laurence Fox showing outstanding acting ability. If you enjoyed Morse - and who didn't? - you cam purchase Lewis with the utmost confidence.

reviewText: As a long-time fan of Inspector Morse, I was pleased to see the Inspector Lewis series produced with some of the same characters and aesthetics as Morse, not to mention some of the same actors returning in different roles. Perhaps you will find yourself doing what I do when I watch a Lewis episode and see a familiar face--try to remember what role that same actor played previously in one or another of the Morse episodes.While I've been glad to see Kevin Whately return in his role as Lewis, it's Detective Sergeant Hathaway who reminds me the most of their predecessor, the intriguingly intelligent and brooding Morse. With his background as a former theology student at Cambridge, it's Hathaway who is most likely to recall some obscure detail, of interest only to scholars, to help solve a case he and Lewis are investigating.If you enjoy Morse, Lewis, and Hathaway as I do, you might also be interested in a recently published novel by John Rather titled Arius, available at Amazon. It's an intelligent thriller that begins at the University of Oxford with a murder resulting from the responses contemporary people have to a religious controversy dating back to the Nicene Council.

reviewText: Inspector Lewis Season 3 is the third year of a British detective series featuring much more fully developed characters than we have in an American series of a similar type. The setting is Oxford England and imparts a real flavor of a university town and their  high-brow attitudes.  The cinematography is clear and precise, each scene well designed to compliment the dialogue and action. Detective Inspector Lewis with his native cunning and practical knowledge contrasts nicely with his partner's (Sgt. Hathaway) higher education and intellectual approach to the cases.  The characters are not the beautiful people from Hollywood, but more more like the average people we know. Unlike the US TV criminal investigators, Lewis and Hathaway solve their cases with intense, detailed interviews and research, and minimal scientific evidence--just like real detectives everywhere.  The cases are usually very complicated and almost impossible for the viewer to figure out.  The only negative is when some of the supporting actors occasionally speak in very accented English voice using some native slang terms.  My wife and I really enjoy watching the "Inspector Lewis" series and highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys good mystery stories.

reviewText: Police veteran DI Lewis (Kevin Whately who used to be a DS on the Inspector Morse mysteries) is paired up with the Cambridge-educated brilliant DS Hathaway (Laurence Fox) on this well-scripted, intelligent British crime drama set in the city of Oxford. The show is highly atmospheric, from the way the crime is set at the beginning of the show, to the development of the plot, one gets a sense that there is much care and detail put into this production, and the result is an engaging crime drama.There are five episodes available here via instant streaming (customers need to pay per episode, and Prime customers get to watch it for free):Counter Culture Blues - rock star Esme Ford returns to Oxford after thirty-five years to re-establish her band Midnight Addiction, though she was thought to have drowned decades earlier. Everything is veiled in secrecy, but not for long, as bodies begin to pile up.The Dead of Winter - DS Hathaway finds the past coming back to haunt him when he is assigned to work on a homicide linked to the Crevecouer Estate, where Hathaway's dad once worked as an estate manager. As he finds himself attracted to an old childhood acquaintance, he finds the family may be harboring some very dark secrets, enough to warrant murder.Dark Matter - A professor of astronomer is found dead in the university observatory soon after confession in church. His widow believes he was having an affair. When another victim is found, Lewis and Hathaway discover that someone has knowledge of the connections between the victims and what motivated the killings. Trouble is, the person who can help is a retired porter who is living in a home and senile.Your Sudden Death Question - It is a Bank Holiday weekend, and Lewis is making plans for a night at the opera with the coroner, Laura (Hathaway is off at a world music festival), but their plans are ruined by a murder at Oxford during a quiz weekend. One of the participants, Ethan Croft, a brilliant ex-student who left Oxford over sexual harassment allegations, is found murdered. Soon after, another participant, Eve, who had been seen with Croft earlier is also found dead. Lewis and Hathaway have to work out if this is merely a crime of passion or something more.Falling Darkness - my favorite of all the episodes here. Dr. Laura Hobson is planning a Halloween get-together with her two ex-college roommates, when one of them, Ligeia, is found murdered. Then, Ellen Jacoby, Laura's other friend, is attacked but survives. What is the killer's motivations and is Laura revealing all that she knows? This episode sees DI Lewis placed in a difficult position as he has to determine if Laura, whom he is extremely fond of, is actually being honest with him, and this places strain on the burgeoning relationship between the two.
summary: DI Lewis and DS Hathaway - an odd but highly competent crime fighting duo
